title: Were there any priests of an unofficial sort for the Israelites before Aaron and before their time in Egypt? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Levites were the tribe of Israelites descended from Levi, one of the twelve sons of Jacob. The priests of Israel were a group of qualified men from within the tribe of the Levites who had responsibility over aspects of tabernacle or temple worship. All priests were to be Levites, according to the Law, but not all Levites were priests. Priests existed prior to the Levites in a general sense. For example, we first see the role of a priest in Genesis 14:18 during Abraham’s time, long before Levi was born. Melchizedek was the king of the town of Salem, which later became Jerusalem. Melchizedek was also said to be “a priest forever” (Psalm 110:4; cf. Hebrews 6:20; 7:17). Pagan nations also had priests for their religious activities. Jethro, the father-in-law of Moses, was the priest of Midian (Exodus 3:1; 18:1). When the Jews received the Law of Moses at Sinai, the Lord gave commands regarding a formal priesthood for Israel. The priests would be males from the tribe of Levi and must meet certain physical and age qualifications in order to serve. In addition, they had to remain ceremonially clean to perform their duties before a holy God. The priests served as mediators between the Israelites and God. They were the ones who performed animal sacrifices on behalf of the people. It was only the priests who were permitted to enter the Holy Place in the tabernacle and, later, the temple. Among these Levitical priests was the high priest. The first high priest was Aaron, the brother of Moses. His sons and their descendants were to serve as the future high priests of the nation of Israel (Exodus 29). Only the high priest was permitted to enter the Most Holy Place in the tabernacle and temple, and that only once per year on the Day of Atonement. Ezra, one of the leaders of the Jews who returned from Babylon, was a Levitical priest (Nehemiah 12:1). Zechariah and Elizabeth, John the Baptist’s parents, were both Levites descended from Aaron (Luke 1:5). Zechariah was a priest, but his son, John, also a Levite, was a prophet, not a priest. By the time of Jesus’ earthly ministry, the Jewish priesthood held much spiritual and political power. In fact, the Jewish chief priests were involved in sentencing Jesus to death. Following the resurrection of Jesus, believers now live under a new covenant in which all Christians are priests: “But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, an holy nation, a peculiar people; that ye should shew forth the praises of him who hath called you out of darkness into his marvellous light” 1 Peter 2:9 We no longer need an earthly mediator between us and God because Jesus has made the final sacrifice on our behalf and acts as our Mediator (Hebrews 10:19–23; 1 Timothy 2:5). The Jewish role of high priest is now fulfilled by Jesus, who serves as our high priest. Jesus’ sacrifice ended our need for continued sacrifices. The Holy Spirit guides and counsels us. The Levitical priesthood was part of the old covenant system of sacrifices. It has been fulfilled in Jesus, and we are now under the new covenant. There is no longer a biblical mandate for priests. Every follower of Christ has access to God, regardless of gender, race, or tribe (Hebrews 7:11–28; Ephesians 3:11–12; Colossians 3:11).

From the earliest times of biblical history people worshipped Jehovah God in one way or another. Cain and Abel practiced a form of worship outside of Eden, the one in an unacceptable manner, the other in a way that pleased our Creator. In so doing they would have been viewed as being priests in some way, although not formally labelled as being such. As the population grew it seems that family heads, the patriarchs, took the lead in establishing the form of worship practiced among the members of different families. Noah is an example of one such patriarch. He took the lead in his family and he was later described described by the apostle Peter as a preacher of righteousness. (2 Peter 2: 5) After the flood we had Melchizadek who was a king and priest in Salem. Tradition states that Shem was this same man. His life overlapped that of Abraham by about 150 years. Abraham was a direct descendant of Shem’s, and he performed a similar function in his own family, as did his own offspring, Isaac and Jacob. Jacobs 12 sons then later developed into what became the nation of Israel, and it appears that during the ensuing 400 and more years from Abrahams time down to the Exodus from Egypt, each family head took the lead in being the spiritual head of his own family. It was these family heads who motivated the preservation of family histories and records, whether oral or written, and it is possible that at least some of what Moses was later inspired to record in his writings came from these earlier family histories. So, all the way down through the centuries, there existed a form of an informal priesthood among the Jews. It kept them united. It kept them separate from other nations overall.

Yes. Before the sin of the Golden Calf, every first born Jewish male was responsible for animal sacrifices and other priestly duties. After the golden calf, The Lord chose the tribe of Levi in place of the first born and there was a big ceremony detailed in the Torah[1] redeeming all the first born Jews from their previous status and conferring this status on the Levites. (All Jewish, male, Non-Levite, first born children today are redeemed in a ceremony as well). Of the tribe of Levi, G-d then chose Aaron and his future, direct, male descendants to carry out the priestly duties with the rest of the Levites helping them. Footnotes[1] Exodus 13 / Hebrew

Before Aaron, there was no communal service to be led by a כהן/’Priest’. The function of the כהן/’Priest’ is to represent the nation, most importantly on Yom Kippur to acheive attonement for Israel. Before Aaron was designated to be the 1st Kohen/Priest, great people were commanded or self-inspired to bring offerings. That is a function of the priests. Noah brought offerings, as did Abraham and Isaac. But those were on an individual level, giving thanks to God. Aaron and his descendants by contrast, perform on a national level, so the answer is no, there were no ‘unofficial priests’ before Aaron.
